awd_titl_txt: The 4th Annual Meeting of SIAM Central States Section
awd_abstract_narration:
The SIAM Central States Section (SIAM CSS https://www.siam.org/sections/central/) was formed in 2014 to serve SIAM members in Arkansas, Colorado, Iowa, Kansas, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The 4th Annual Meeting of SIAM Central States Section will be held 10/5-10/7, 2018 on the Norman campus of the University of Oklahoma. The url for the conference website is http://www.math.ou.edu/conferences/siam2018 .

The theme of this conference will be centered around applied and computational Mathematics. This award will be used solely to support junior researchers (students/postdocs/early career faculty), minorities, people with disability and colleagues from 4-year colleges. Our long-term goal is to build a stronger computational and applied Math program throughout all the central states. The SIAM CSS annual conference series provides a very important platform for computational and applied mathematicians to exchange knowledge and network with experts from all over the U.S. and other countries. This conference will give ample opportunity for people to interact at discussions during the breaks, between talks, as well as after the talks. In particular we expect participants from the central states (that may or may not present at the conference) to have the opportunity to establish interactions with researchers that they would not often have a chance to meet in this part of the country.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 4th annual meeting of SIAM Central State Section (CSS) was held on University of Oklahoma Norman campus during October 5-7, 2018. The conference activity includes 4 plenary talks, 162 talks given in 14 mini-symposia and 1 contributed talk session, as well as a poster session. This conference attracted 225 participants, and majority is junior researchers (graduate student/postdoc/tenure-track faculty). The main theme of the conference is on the advancement in the area of computational mathematics. This conference had provided many opportunities for the participants to network with each other. A special issue at Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics was devoted to the research outcomes disseminated in this conference. This project has offered support to 37 students, postdocs and assistant professors (11 females) including African American and 4-year college colleagues. 


The 5th annual meeting of SIAM CSS was held on Iowa State University campus during October 19-20, 2019. There were 178 registered participants, and 144 participants delivered presentations. SIAM CSS 2019 conference includes three plenary talks, and 16 mini-symposia with 144 mini-symposium talks. During this regional flagship conference, participants including junior, mid-career and senior researchers from the central region and beyond had many opportunities to discuss their research work and professional development plan among themselves and with the three plenary speakers. A special issue of Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics (JCAM) has been devoted to this conference. This project has offered travel and lodging support to 19 undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs and assistant professors (7 females) including African American and 4-year college colleagues. 


This project also provided additional support to the SIAM CSS Computational and Applied Mathematics (CAM) Forum, which launched in the Spring of 2023. The format of this forum is virtual via Zoom. Twenty talks have been delivered by speakers from 19 different institutions through this project period. Majority of the speakers are established applied and computational mathematicians and are from top universities, and most of their home institutions are not in the central region of the US, which made it particularly difficult for the colleagues in the central states to interact with otherwise. Most of the speakers granted us the permission to record their talks and the recorded talks are publicly available through the forum's website. The participants range from faculty/postdoc/graduate students to retired faculty and government lab research scientist, as well as industry researchers. This forum provided excellent opportunities for all the participants, especially the researchers who do not have access to travel fund, for example, graduate students and postdocs, to have interaction with leading applied and computational mathematicians.


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Ying Wang
